{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3417490,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T02:10:48.568Z","cooked":"

Next season our team plans on doing swerve, mostly because it would be a good challenge and it would be fun, my team also estimate around a 20,000$ price for a robot? Does this seem right?

Anyways, I was wondering what kind of motors we should use for it, I know a lot of teams used kraken motors this year since they are powerful, and we have the budget for them, but I’m worried about the power draw of 8 krakens running in unison, should I not be worried, should there be something to implement that makes this not a worry, or should we use something like Neo 1.1s to change direction of the wheels while the krakens are doing the actual spinning of them. Also should we consider the new Neo Vortexes instead of Krakens?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T02:10:48.568Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":62,"reads":545,"readers_count":544,"score":434.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/1","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3417494,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T02:41:26.031Z","cooked":"
10219Ryba:

my team also estimate around a 20,000$ price for a robot? Does this seem right?

You’re an order of magnitude too high. It can easily be a few thousand dollars, but single digit thousands.

10219Ryba:

I know a lot of teams used kraken motors this year since they are powerful, and we have the budget for them, but I’m worried about the power draw of 8 krakens running in unison, should I not be worried, should there be something to implement that makes this not a worry, or should we use something like Neo 1.1s to change direction of the wheels while the krakens are doing the actual spinning of them. Also should we consider the new Neo Vortexes instead of Krakens?

The appeal of the Kraken isn’t so much the power (though that’s nice) as it is CTRE’s software libraries–particularly if you’re running SDS or WCP modules.

Teams who fully embrace CTRE’s platform–Krakens or Falcons plus CANcoders and Pigeon IMU–seem to have had a particularly straightforward path on their code compared to teams who ran REV’s setup.

Teams who ran all REV on their swerves–MAXSwerve with NEO/NEO 550/NEO Vortex–seemed to have good results overall.

Teams who mixed and matched needed more software support than I could muster with my deeper-than-average rolodex and had a higher risk of having to pivot to an AM14U two weeks before the first event. Not that I’m frustrated by that six months later or anything.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T02:42:06.273Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":539,"readers_count":538,"score":232.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"says you should come to SCRIW in October"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/2","custom_user_title":"says you should come to SCRIW in October","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417500,"name":"Steven Carmain","username":"Steven_Carmain","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/f07891/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T03:01:31.510Z","cooked":"

For a basic swerve you are looking at:
Per corner:
MK4i - $365
Kracken - $199x2
CanCoder - $90
Total - $853/corner

General Robot parts:
Rio - $485
PDP - $240 (you want the Rev one for 4 extra power slots)
Radio - $179
RSL - $60+
Pigeon2 - $199
Frame Stock - $100? (I’m the software guy, just a couple 1x2 tubes)
Total ~$1250

So, to build a swerve chassis, you are looking at ~$4500, or ~$3500 for the swerve specific parts. You can get some cheaper parts also, the MaxSwerve is $65 cheaper, the Thrifty Mag encoders are $30 each, any gyro should work. Neos are probably the cheapest motor you can use to have the power during matches.

Our team this year went Falcon drive, Neo turn. (our sister team was all Neo) They worked fine past the initial setup. The turn motors barely run, so you only really have 4 Krackens using your current. It just made wiring harder, as you had to deal with the speed controller of the Neo, and you can’t use the CTRE CANifier for faster bus communication, as Rev products are incompatible. You really aren’t saving that much either going with Neos for turns. ($48 motor + $90 speed controller vs $199 for the Kraken)

The real debate of Neo/Neo Vortex/Kraken/Falcon is really an engineering challenge. See this discussion thread here: Is the fastest swerve the best? You’ll find a great discussion of what gearing to try, and you might realize the slower gearing are better because you spend longer in a match accelerating instead of top speed. Try the Recalc calculator too to play with the gear ratios and motor combinations and see what might work for you. I think you’ll find the higher torque of the Kraken/Falcons to be your best bet.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T03:01:31.510Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":476,"readers_count":475,"score":175.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Steven Carmain","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/drive","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":3},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/is-the-fastest-swerve-the-best/469899","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Is the fastest swerve the best?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1737,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer/Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/3","custom_user_title":"Programmer/Drive Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417507,"name":"Chris Harrison","username":"char","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/char/{size}/159140_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T03:52:29.686Z","cooked":"

Your robot cost will highly depend on the region in which you compete.

In my region, the cost per year for a robot is between 5K-10K.

The minimal cost presently to adopt MK4 swerve is around 4K. And that’s just for the pod components and motors. This includes a total of 5 pods: 4 active pods + 1 backup pod.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T03:55:09.322Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":417,"readers_count":416,"score":93.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Chris Harrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49328,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Controls Mentor. Quantum Physics & Computer Science FTW!"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/4","custom_user_title":"Controls Mentor. Quantum Physics & Computer Science FTW!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417516,"name":"","username":"Ugydukin","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/278dde/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T04:48:44.785Z","cooked":"

I really reccomend the set of 8 krakens for your swerve, also your best option for swerve would definitely be the MK4C swerve modules from SDS, many teams run 8 kraken swerve with no issue of power draw, not even counting for the 4-6 more motors they could be running on top of that on their mechanisms. One way to save a bit of money could be plain neos on steer, but the controllers can be a pain to find space for. As far as krakens vs vortexes, krakens are pretty all round beefier motors, with less max free speed but more torque and software support. $20k should leave you with a LOT of room for a whole functioning robot, our team, with spare parts and extra stock metal included, probably spent close to 15k on a very fleshed out robot.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T04:48:44.785Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":392,"readers_count":391,"score":108.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65614,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ugydukin"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/5","custom_user_title":"ugydukin","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417547,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T10:06:40.558Z","cooked":"
10219Ryba:

I’m worried about the power draw of 8 krakens running in unison,

I wouldn’t be too worried here. Your steering motors won’t pull very much current at all, since they aren’t doing much work. The drive motors can be current limited if you desire, which will allow you to cut some drivetrain power in favor of keeping your battery happy.

Over the summer we moved to a all-CTRE drive base to be able to take advantage of the CTRE swerve library. It was easy to setup and get going with the wizard .

Krakens are also nice because they are simple to wire. Controller and motor are all integrated, so there are fewer wire connection and potentially failure points, compared to neos*.

To do all that though, you need to commit 8 krakens, 4 CANcoders, and a pigeon 2.0 to your swerve. If you can afford it though, I think you can get up and running quickly.

*Neo vortex’s have this advantage too, but I believe had some trouble with the loads on the mk4i and could break.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T10:10:05.185Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":352,"readers_count":351,"score":145.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Lexeo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/6","custom_user_title":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417612,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T17:03:49.938Z","cooked":"
Lexeo:

The drive motors can be current limited if you desire,

And should be

@Lexeo is spot on here - it’s not just the motors themselves (which are solid), it’s the entire ecosystem that is so attractive…

10219Ryba:

I’m worried about the power draw of 8 krakens running in unison

as with any brushless motor, current limits are your friend.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T17:32:52.391Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":285,"readers_count":284,"score":187.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Emerson OHara","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43759,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/8","custom_user_title":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417671,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T19:56:54.352Z","cooked":"

We went through this last year before we purchased the Rev MaxSwerve with motors and motor controller bundle for around $2880 for 4 corners. We ended up with a 5th module (really a good call).

To figure it out we worked on a spreadsheet and compared the models available at the time and their various configurations to try and help us compare. Math was based on using the cheapest motor combos possible for each swerve. We have falcons in house so our math may vary. This was a group activity to help them all understand the costs of moving to swerve on a limited budget.

Swerve Comparison.xlsx (18.8 KB)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T19:57:03.177Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":261,"readers_count":260,"score":87.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/uploads/short-url/AhEDGeUKlRugQYFDRIrJ7xfMvZc.xlsx","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/9","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417687,"name":"tkchan","username":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T20:49:25.118Z","cooked":"

I went 1 step more, I started with a 3d printed swerve base. You can download all the models from the vendors. We did the MaxSwerve so we started with there first. I even started with printed gears (YES), knowing full well that they will burn out (they do). But quickly give me an excuses to have the students to take it all apart and observe wear patterns and a chance to work on dissembly. You can buy all the comparable bearings from Amazon (metal gears I ended up still buying from REV). We will be repeating this again with a new group of students this year.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T20:49:25.118Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"tkchan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":20632,"username":"kingc95","name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26389,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"think outside of the box from time to time"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/10","custom_user_title":"think outside of the box from time to time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417690,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T20:56:30.524Z","cooked":"

We made them put together a single 3d printed mk4 module (as much as possible without bearings and belts) and said okay. Now take all those steps times 4. Can we do this? Didn’t look at wear and tear or even run it. Just can they follow the steps of a complex COTs module.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-08-23T20:57:51.171Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":235,"readers_count":234,"score":52.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470156,"topic_slug":"budget-for-swerve","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26389,"username":"tkchan","name":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/budget-for-swerve/470156/11","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417695,"name":"Ryan Dognaux","username":"Ryan_Dognaux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_dognaux/{size}/129138_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-23T21:38:44.861Z","cooked":"

We’ve got a pretty good deal going for 5 modules, frame and tread, feel free to check it out:

The Thrifty Bot

Pre-Order: Thrifty Swerve: 5 Modules + Frame + Tread Bundle

Whatever solution you pursue… invest in at least one spare module complete with spare motors and encoders. (I love that the thriftybot deal is for 5 modules…that’s awesome)

Something will fail, and it’s easiest to swap the whole module and debug later.

LPryor:

Something will fail, and it’s easiest to swap the whole module and debug later.

@brandonmcd we used our spare MaxSwerve spare module once for a full swap and later the one we removed we disassembled for the encoder when one was smashed at an off-season. I think, could be remembering this wrong. Definitely definitely agree that you should always have an extra module on hand.

as others have said, $20k price for a robot seems a tad high. I believe our robot all in was maybe $10k, including buying 10 krakens and 5 SDS Mk4i kits, including some upgrade parts, and many spares, bits of stock, and parts that didn’t end up working. Overall, most of our robots end up averaging around $8k (2023 and 2022 robots were both around 8k). Electronics and drivetrain are always the most expensive subsystems, especially this year, where we bought more sensors, limelights, and many expensive CTRE products.

I believe our total cost (including shop fixes/upgrades and 9k for registration) was maybe around 20-24k? All of these are just estimates however.

When considering swerve…don’t forget about the extras…extra frame (for those hard impacts), extra gears for the wear and tear, and whatever you think MAY break or be damaged.

Also consider compatibility of motors for the modules and what extra parts you need to make them fit. Krakens on SDS Mk4i needs the half moon adapter to make them fit.

Be mindful of the parts required. Good luck on the upcoming season!!!
